availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

notesStmt.note: Ascribed to the press of Frederick Green by Wheeler. Date of publication supplied by Winans, q.v. Dated 1783 by Evans.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A CATALOGUE OF THE ANNAPOLIS CIRCULATING LIBRARY.

A CATALOGUE OF THE ANNAPOLIS CIRCULATING LIBRARY, Consisting of near FIFTEEN HUNDRED VOLUMES, IN Agriculture, Arithmetic, Astronomy, Biography, Chymistry, Commerce, Gardening, Geography, Geometry, History, Husbandry, Law, Military Affairs, Mathematics, Navigation, Painting, Physic, Rhetoric, Surgery, Surveying, Voyages, Travels, Plays, Novels, Magazines, &c.

Which are lent to read, BY STEPHEN CLARK, Bookseller, Stationer and Bookbinder, IN CHURCH-STREET, ANNAPOLIS, Where may be had, All new Books, Stationary Wares of all Sorts, School-Books, Jewellery, Plated 〈…〉 and a great many other Articles 〈…〉 Goods too tedious to mention.

Books bought, 〈…〉
▪

div.head: CONDITIONS, To be observed and consented to by every subscriber to CLARK'S CIRCULATING LIBRARY.
div.p: I. Every yearly subscriber to pay one guinea; half yearly subscribers to pay three dollars; quarterly subscribers to pay twelve shillings and six-pence; monthly subscribers to pay one dollar; single book to a nonsubscriber, (a deposit being made) twelves, six-pence, octavo one shilling.
II. In town one book at a time to be allowed, to be changed once a day, and no more; to subscribers in the country two books.
III. No book to be kept longer than one week in town, and two in the country.
IV. Subscribers to pay one eighth of a dollar for their catalogue.
V. All books lost or abused, leaves folded down, torn or wrote upon, to be replaced in the library, or if the book lost or abused belongs to a set, the set to be taken and paid for.

VI. That so long as subscribers (through any cause whatsoever) do keep a book or books in their hands, belonging to the library, beyond the time they agreed and paid for, they shall be deemed subscribers, whether they read or not, and pay accordingly.

VII. Subscribers, to prevent being disappointed in the books they want, are to send a list of six or eight different numbers taken from the catalogue, as thus,
50
100
200
500

div.head: HISTORY, &c. FOLIO, QUARTO AND OCTAVO.
div.p:
BURNET's (bishop) history of his own time, 2 vols.
Vol. 1. Contains affairs from the restoration of king Charles II to the settlement of king William and queen Mary, at the revolution.
Vol. 2. From the revolution to the conclusion of the treaty of peace at Utrecht, in the reign of queen Anne, to which is added the author's life, by the editor.

Universal history from the earliest account of time to the present, compiled from original authors, and illustrated with maps, cuts, notes, chronological and other tables, 7 vols.
Vol. 1. Contains history of the world to the birth of Abraham; history of Egypt to Alexander the Great; history of Egypt, of the Moabites, Syrians, Phoenicians and Holy Land; history of the Jews to the Babylonish captivity; history of the Assyrians, Babylonians and Phrygians.
Vol. 2. History of the Medes, Persians, Scythians, Lydians, Attica, Sparta, Athenians, Lacedoemonians,
Thebans, Achaia, Athens and Ionia.
Vol. 3. Sicily, Syracuse, Rhodes, Macedonians, Seleucidae in Syria, the Ptolemies, the Armenians, kingdoms of Pontus, Cappadocia, Pergamus, Thrace, Epirus, &c.
Vol. 4. History of the Jews from their return from the Babylonish captivity to the destruction of Jerusalem by Titus Vespasian, with an account of their dispersion and condition to the present time; of the Parthians, Persians, Roman history to the end of the sedition of the Gracchi.
Vol. 5. Roman history from the end of the sedition of the Gracchi to the death of Domitian, the last of the 12 Caesars.
Vol. 6. Roman history from the death of Domitian to the taking of Constantinople by the Latins; history of the Carthaginians to the commencement of the second Punic war.
Vol. 7. History of the Carthaginians from the second Punic war to the destruction of Carthage by Aemilianus, Numidians, Mauritanians, Ethiopians, Arabs, Spaniards, Gauls, ancient Germans, Britons, Hunns, Goths, Franks, Lombards, &c. with a copious index to the foregoing 7 volumes.
Ralegh's (Sir Walter) history of the world in five books, to which is prefixed the life of the author, 2 vols. in 1.
An Inquiry into the prices of wheat, malt, and other provisions as sold in England, from the year 1000 to the year 1765, 1 vol.

div.head: QUARTO.
div.p: Description of East-Florida, with a journal kept, by John Bartram of Philadelphia, 1 vol.
General history of the science and practice of music, by John Hawkins, 5 vols.
History of the discovery and conquest of the Canary Islands, by George Glase, 1 vol.
Poetical works of the late William Dunkin, 2 vols.
Rise, progress and present state, of the northern governments, viz. the United Provinces, Denmark, Sweden, Russia and Poland, by J. Williams, 2 vols.
Collection of the most remarkable trials, in which the most remarkable of the state trials is included, 2 vols.
Travels through the middle settlements of North America in the years 1759 and 1760, by Andrew Burnaby, 1 vol.
Voyage round the world in his Britannic majesty's sloop Resolution, commanded by captain James Cook, during the years 1772,—3,—4,— 5, by George Foster, 2 vols.
Observations made during a voyage round the world, on physical geography, natural history, and ethic philosophy, by John Reinold Foster, 1 vol.
Minor Atlas, by H. Moll, 1 vol.

div.head: OCTAVO.
div.p:
Annual 〈◊〉 , or a view of the history, politics 〈…〉 ,
clusive, in which is included the most complet • history extant of the war between Great-Britain and the United States of America, also a collection of interesting and authentic papers, tending to elucidate the history, 26 vols.
Vol. 1. 1758.
2. 1759.
3. 1760.
4. 1761.
5. 1762.
6. 1763.
7. 1764.
8. 1765.
9. 1766.
10. 1767.
11. 1768.
12. 1769.
13. 1770.
14. 1771.
15. 1772.
16. 1773.
17. 1774.
18. 1775.
19. 1776.
20. 1777.
21. 1778.
22. 1779.
23. 1780.
24. 1781.
25. 1782.
26. Index to the whole.
Monthly review, or literary journals, from 〈…〉
Gentlemens and ladies magazines for the years 1778 to 1783 inclusive, in 6 vols.
Hibernian magazine for the years 1778 to 1783 inclusive, in 6 vols.

div.head: HISTORIES, VOYAGES, TRAVELS, &c.
div.p: Guthries history of the world from the creation to the present time, 13 vols.
Hook's Roman history, from the building of Rome to the ruin of the commonwealth, 8 vols.
Ferguson's history of the progress and termination of the Roman republic, 3 vols.
Raynal's philosophical and political history of the settlements and trade of the Europeans in the East and West-Indies, 4 vols.
Campbell's political survey of Great-Britain, being a series of reflections on the situation and land, inhabitants, revenues, colonies and commerce, of that island, 4 vols.

History of modern Europe, with an account of the decline and fall of the Roman empire, and a view of the progress of society from the fifth to the eighteenth century, in a series of letters from a nobleman to his son, 2 vols.
Hume's history of England from the invasion of Julius Caesar to the revolution in 1688, 8 vols.
History of Ireland, from the earliest accounts, up, 1 vol.
History of Louisiana, 1 vol.
History of the island of Minorca, 1 vol.

History (military) of Europe from the commencement of the war with Spain in 1739, to the treaty of Aix la Chapelle in 1748, 1 vol. Millot's elements of general history, ancient and modern, 5 vols.
Vol. 1 contains history of the Egyptians, Medes and Persians, Grecians and Romans.
Vol. 2. History of the Romans from the year 552 to 620.
Vol. 3. Modern history, first Epocha to the sixth Epocha.
Vol. 4. From the sixth Epocha to the thirteenth Epocha.
Vol. 5. From the thirteenth Epocha to the beginning of the reign of Louis XIVth.
Robertson's history of America, 2 vols.
— history of Scotland, during the reigns of queen Mary, and of king James VIth, till his accession to the crown of England, 2 vols.
Steuart's history of Scotland, from the establishment of the reformation to the death of queen Mary, 2 vols.
Cook's voyages in the years 1772, 1773, 1774 and 1775, 2 vols.
— Last voyages in the years 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779 and 1780, 3 vols.
— Voyage in 1772, 1 vol.
Coxe's travels into Poland, Russia, Sweden and Denmark, interspersed with historical relations, and political inquiries, 3 vols.
Forrest's voyage to New-Guinea and the Mo-
Gulliver's travels, by Swift, 1 vol.
Dillon's travels through Spain, with a view to illustrate the natural history and physical geography of that kingdom, 1 vol.
Irwin's voyage up the Red Sea, on the coasts of Arabia and Egypt, 1 vol.
Swinburn's travels in the two Sicilies, in the years 1777, 1778, 1779 and 1780, 1 vol.
Pennant's tour in Scotland, 2 vols.
— Journey from Chester to London, 1 vol.

Account of the voyages undertaken by the order of his Britannic majesty for making discoveries in the southern hemisphere, and successively performed by commodore Byron, captain Wallis, captain Carteret, and captain Cook, in the Dolphin, the Swallow, and the Endeavour, by John Hawkesworth, 3 vols.
Tour through Wales, 1 vol.
Tour through Sicily and Malta, in a series of letters to William Beckford, Esq from P. Brydone, F. R. S. 1 vol.
Lothian's history of the United Provinces of the Netherlands, 1 vol.

Letters on Iceland, containing observations on the civil, literary, ecclesiastical and natural history, antiquities, volcanos, basaltes, hot springs, customs, dress, manners of the inhabitants, &c. made during a voyage, undertaken in the year 1772, by Joseph Banks, Esq 1 vol.

History of the origin and progress of the late war, from the commencement to the exchange of the ratification of peace▪ between Great-Britain,
France and Spain, on the 10th of February, 1763, 2 vols.

History of the war in America, between Great-Britain and the colonies, from its commencement to the end of the year 1778, in which its origin, progress and operations, are faithfully related, together with anecdotes and characters of the different commanders, and accounts of such personages in congress as have distinguished themselves during the contest, 2 vols.
History of the late revolution in Sweden, 1 vol.
Observations on Italy and its inhabitants, by Thomas Nugent, L. L. D. 2 vols.

Geographical dictionary, containing an historical and critical account of the lives and writings of the most eminent persons of every nation, 12 vols.
Vol. 1. Containing, life of Adam, Aelfred, Alexander, Anderson, Arnulph, Atkins, Atterbury, &c.
Vol. 2. Bacon, Barlowe, Beveridge, Blake, Bossuet, Boyle, Briggs, Burton, &c.
Vol. 3. Caesar, Cartes, Cavendish, Chambers, Cicero, Cleopatra, Coke, Columbus, Cowley, Cromwell, &c.
Vol. 4. Dacier, Davenport, Davereux, Diogenes, Drake, Dryden, Dudley, Eachard, Epicharmus, Erasmus, Euclid, Eugene, &c.
Vol. 5. Faber, Fleetwood, Forbes, Fowler, Fuller, Gardiner, Gat • ker, Gay, Gilpin, Godwin, &c.
Vol. 6. Grabe, Graunt, Gregory, Grey, Grotius, Hall, Handel, Hoffman, Hooper, Humphrey, Hyde, &c.
Vol. 7. James, Johnson, Julian, Junius, Juvenal, Latimer, L'Estrange, Lilly, Lister, Livius, &c.
Vol. 8. Lokman, Lucian, Luther, Mahomet, Masson, Middleton, Moliere, More, Nelson, Newton, &c.
Vol. 9. Octavia, Oldenburgh, Origen, Owen, Pamelius, Parsons, Patrick, Paul, Penn, Peter the Great, Philips, Pococke, &c.
Vol. 10. Quintilianu • , Rawlegh, Rochester, Rubins, Sallustius, Seneca, Shakespear, Sydney, Socrates, Spencer, Stanley, Steele, &c.
Vol. 11. Sto • , Swift, Tas • o, Thomson, Tillotson, Vandyke, Virgil, Walton, Whiston, Wood, Wren, Xenophon, &c.
Vol. 12. Alexander, Barrington, Catharine, Churchill, Cromwell, Doddridge, Hervey, King, Quin, Sloane, Thomas, Walpole, &c.
Biographical history of England, from 〈◊〉 the Great to the revolution, by J. Granger 4 vols.
Campbell's lives of the British admirals, 5 vols.
History of the famous preacher, Friar Gerand de Campazas, 2 vols.

Johnson's lives of the English poets, and a criticism on their works, 3 vols.
Vol. 1. Contains, li • e Cowley, Waller, Mil • ton, Butler, Dryden, Denham, Sprat, Ros • common,
Yalden, Otway, Duke, Dorset, Halifax, Stepney, Walsh, Garth, King, J. Philips, Smith, Pomfret, Hughes.
Vol. 2. Addison, Blackmore, Sheffield, Granville, Rowe, Tickell, Congreve, Fenton, Prior, Pope, Swift.
Vol. 3. Gay, Broom, Pitt, Parnell, A. Philips, Watts, Savage, Somerville, Thomson, Hammond, Collins, Young, Dyer, Mallet, Shenstone, A • en • de, Lyttelton, West, Gray.

Life of Edward, earl of Clarendon, lord high chancellor of England, and chancellor of the universities of Oxford. 1. An account of the chancellor's life, from his birth to the restoration in 1660. 2. A continuation of the same, and of his history of the grand rebellion, from the restoration to his banishment in 1667, 3 vo • s.
Life of Benvenuto Cellini, a Florentine artist, containing a variety of curious and interesting particulars, relative to painting, sculpture and architecture, by Thomas Nugent, 2 vols.
History of the life of Reginald Pole, 2 vols.
Life of Richard Nash▪ Esq late master of the ceremonies at Bath, 1 vol.
Life of Henry Prine, of Wales, eldest son of king James Ist, by Thomas Birch, D. D. 1 vol.
Essay upon the life, writings and character, of Dr. Jonathan Swift, by Deane Swift, Esq 1 vol.
Life of Pope Clement IVth, (Ganganelli), 1 vol.
Memoirs of Peter Henry Bruce, Esq a military officer in the services of Russia, Prussia and Great-Britain, containing, account of his travels in Germany, Russia, Tartary, Turkey, the West-Indies, &c.

Universal Biography, ancient and modern, containing a circumstantial and curious detail of the lives, actions, opinions, writings and characters, of the most celebrated persons of both sexes, of all ranks, in all countries, and in all ages, alphabetically disposed, by Thomas Flloyd, Esq 3 vols.
Watson's history of the reign of Philip the IId, king of Spain, 3 vols.
— history of the reign of Philip the IIId, 1 vol.
Robertson's history of the emperor Charles the Vth, 4 vols.

Memoirs of the bashaw count Bonneval, from his birth to his death, interspersed throughout with an entertaining diversity of secret intrigues, amorous adventures, military and political atchievements, being, in effect, the secret history of Europe for the current century, 1 vol.
History of the chevalier Bayard, by Joseph Sterling, 1 vol.

div.head: DIVINITY, AGRICULTURE, &c. OCTAVO.
div.p: Dutton (Anne) letters on spiritual subjects, to which are prefixed, memoirs of the dealings of God with her in her last sickness, 2 vols.
Essay on faith, and its connexions with good works, by John Rotheram, 1 vol.
Farquhar's sermons on several subjects, 1 vol.
Forsayeth's life of Jesus Christ, 1 vol.
Jortin's sermons on different subjects, 4 vols.
Rowe (Elizabeth) letters from the dead to the living, to which are added, letters moral and entertaining, in prose and verse, with the author's life, 1 vol.
Sherlock's sermons, 2 vols.
Seed's posthumous works, 3 vols.
Works of Flavius Josephus, the Jewish historian, with the life of Josephus, by William Whiston, 5 vols.
An essay on the proper lessons appointed by the liturgy of the church of England to be read on Sundays and chief festivals throughout the year, 4 vols. by W. Wogan.
Mason's spiritual treasury for the children of God, consisting of a meditation for each day in the year, 2 vols.
Universal salvation, the Grand Thing aimed at in the scheme of God—as opened in the New Testament writings, and intrusted with Jesus Christ to bring into effect, 2 vols.
Hume's dialogues of natural religion, 1 vol.
Kaime's essay on the principles of morality and natural religion, 1 vol.

Priestley's examination of Dr. Reid's inquiry into the human mind, on the principles of common sense—Dr. Beattie's essay on the nature and immutability of truth—and Dr. Oswald's appeal to common sense in behalf of religion, 1 vol.
Principal truths of natural religion, defended and illustrated, in nine dissertations, by H. S. Reimarus, 1 vol.
Conformity between modern and ancient ceremonies, wherein is proved, by incontestible authorities, that the ceremonies of the church of Rome are entirely derived from the Heathens, 1 vol.
Treatise concerning eternal and immutable morality, by Ralph Cudworth, 1 vol.
Universal prayer book, or Christian assistant, containing, meditations and prayers for every day in the week—A discourse on the nature and end of the Lord's Supper, 1 vol.
Common prayer book illustrated and explained, 1 vol.
Whole duty of man, 1 vol.
Dodd's thoughts in prison, in five parts, viz. the imprisonment, retrospect, public punishment, the trial, futurity, to which is added his last prayer, written the night before his death, 1 vol.
Anderson on the means of exciting a spirit of national industry, 2 vols.
Dossie's memoirs of agriculture, and other oeconomical arts, 1 vol.
Ellis's practice of farming and husbandry, in all sorts of soils, according to the latest improvements, 1 vol.
Farmer's guide in hoeing and stocking farms, 2 vols.
Tull's horse-hoeing husbandry, or an essay on the principles of tillage and vegetation, 1 vol.
Young's course of experimental agriculture, containing an exact register of all the business transacted during five years—on near three hundred acres of various soils, 4 vols.

div.head: TRADE, PHYSIC, MEDICINE, CHIRURGERY, &c.
div.p: Sheffield on the commerce of the American states, containing, tables of the imports and exports of Great-Britain, to and from all parts, from 1700 to 1782, also, the exports of America, &c. with remarks on those tables, on British navigation, &c. 1 vol.
Physical and chemical essay, translated from the original Latin of Sir Torbern Bergman, by Edmund Cullin, 2 vols.
Cullin (William) first lines in the practice of physic, 4 vols.
Buchan's domestic medicine, being an attempt to render the medical art more useful, by shewing people what is in their own power, both with respect to the prevention and cure of diseases, 1 vol.
Lewis's experimental history of the materia medica, or of the natural and artificial substances made use of in medicine, 2 vols.
Mead's medical works, 1 vol.
Medical and philosophical commentaries, by a society of physicians in Edinburgh, 9 vols.
Pott's chirurgical works, 2 vols.
Watson's chemical essays, 1 vol.
Tissot on health, 1 vol.
New Edinburgh dispensatory, 1 vol.
Haller on morbid bodies, 1 vol.

div.head: LETTERS, MISCELLANIES, POEMS, &c.
div.p: Boulter's letters to several ministers of state in England, and some others, 1 vol.

Chesterfield's letters to his son, 4 vols.
Cunningham's poems, chiefly pastoral, 1 vol.
Cook's elements of dramatic criticism, 1 vol.
Dalrymple's tactics, 1 vol.

Baker's companion to the play-house, containing, historical and critical memoirs, and original anecdotes, of British and Irish dramatic writers, from the commencement of our theatrical exhibitions, amongst whom are some of the most celebrated actors, 2 vols.
Hanway on the importance of the rising generation of the labouring part of our fellow-subjects, 2 vols.
Letters by Arthur Capel, earl of Essex, 1 vol.
Lawson's lectures concerning oratory, 1 vol.
Hughes's letters, and several other eminent persons, deceased, 3 vols.
Raspe's account▪ of some German volcanos, 1 vol.
Parnell's poems, 1 vol.
Remarks on the life and writings of Dr. Jonathan Swift, by the earl of Orrery, 1 vol.
Observations on lord Orrery's remarks on the life and writings of Dr. Jonathan Swift, 1 vol.
Swift's works, 20 vols.

Wood's essay on the original genius and writings of Homer, 1 vol.
Lyttelton's works, 2 vols.
Orations of Demosthenes, by Thomas Leland, 2 vols.

div.p: Blackstone's commentaries on the laws of England, 4 vols.

Euclid's elements of geometry, 1 vol.

div.head: TRAVELS, TRIALS, COOKERY, &c.
div.p: Burney's tour through Germany, 2 vols.
— tour through France and Italy, 1 vol.
Trial of Augustus Keppel, 1 vol.
Dalrymple's practice of modern cookery, 1 vol.
Bellegarde's models of conversation for persons of polite education, 1 vol.

div.head: DICTIONARIES. OCTAVO.
div.p: Bailey's dictionary, 1 vol.

Ainsworth's Latin ditto. English ditto. 1 vol.

div.head: HISTORY, VOYAGES, TRAVELS, &c. DUO DECIMO.
div.p: 〈◊〉 history, by Voltaire, 4 vols.
Chalon's history of France, 2 vols.
Goldsmith's Grecian history from the earliest state to the death of Alexander the great, 2 vols.
Goldsmith's Roman history, 1 vol.
Historical account of North-America, 1 vol.
Rollin's ancient history, 10 vols.
— method of teaching and studying the belles lettres, 4 vols.
Rapin's history of England by question and answer, 1 vol.
Brydone's tour through Sicily and Malta, 2 vols.
Johnson's journey to the western islands of Scotland, 1 vol.
Richard's tour from London to Petersborough, and from thence to Moscow, 1 vol.
Sterne's sentimental journey through France and Italy, 4 vols. complete in 1.
Tour through the island of Great-Britain, divided into circuits or journies, 4 vols.
Tour through Ireland, wherein the present state of that kingdom is considered, and the most noted cities, towns, seats, buildings, loughs, &c. described, 1 vol.
Thicknesse's journey through France and Spain, 2 vols.
Smollett's travels through France and Italy, containing observations on characters, customs, religion, government, police, commerce, arts and antiquities, 2 vols.
Twis's travels through Portugal and Spain in 1772 and 1773, 2 vols.
Travels in Europe, Asia and Africa, describing characters, customs, manners, laws, and productions of nature and art, 2 vols.
Andrews's remarks on English and French ladies, in a series of letters, 1 vol.
Remarks on the characters and manners of the French, in a series of letters, 2 vols.
Voyages and adventures of captain Robert Boyle in several parts of the world.
Barrow's naval history of Great-Britain, with the lives of the most illustrious admirals and commanders, 4 vols.
Bolingbrooke on the study and use of history.

div.head: MISCELLANEOUS PERIODICAL POEMS, &c. DUO DECIMO.
div.p:
Addison's miscellaneous works in verse and prose, 3 vols.
Vol. 1. Contains campaign, and other poems.
Vol 2. Rosamond, an opera, Cato, a tragedy, Drummer, a comedy, count Tariff and Whig Examiner.
Vol. 3. Usefulness of ancient medals, &c.
Addison's freeholder, 1 vol.
Art of painting, of Charles Alphonse du Fresnoy, translated into the English verse by Mr. Mason, 1 vol.
Turner's introduction of the arts and sciences, 1 vol.
Art of knowing mankind, 1 vol.
Brookes's art of angling, 1 vol.
Art of speaking, 1 vol.
Ovid's art of love, 1 vol.
Brown's works, serious and comical, in prose and verse, with his remarks, 4 vols.
Collier on ridicule, or what it is that makes a man ridiculous, and the means to avoid it, 2 vols.
Goldsmith's citizen of the world, 2 vols.
Collection and selection of English prologues and epilogues, commencing with Shakespear, and concluding with Garrick, 4 vols.
Country gentleman's companion, 1 vol.
Description of three hundred animals, with a particular account of the whale fishery, 1 vol.
Dodington's diary from March 1748—9 to 1761, 1 vol.
Davies's dramatic miscellanies, consisting of critical observations on several plays of Shakespear.
Secret history of the university of Oxford in several essays, 1 vol.
Home's experiments on bleaching, 1 vol.
